docs.lead_paragraph: Update | 8:39 p.m. This is an updated version of an article published earlier on Friday.

headline.main: Cancer Society Protests Senate's Proposed Cap on Benefits

docs.abstract: The American Cancer Society protests a small change in the Senate health bill that might result in caps on insurance benefits for patients.
docs.snippet: The American Cancer Society protests a small change in the Senate health bill that might result in caps on insurance benefits for patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: When a worker loses a job, he or she is eligible to maintain health insurance under the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act, or Cobra. While Cobra payments are typically quite expensive, a federal subsidy has recently eased the financial burden of Cobra for laid-off workers.

headline.main: Coping With the Costs of Cobra

docs.abstract: A federal subsidy to ease the burden of Cobra insurance payments is running out. Today's Patient Money column offers advice on how to cope.
docs.snippet: A federal subsidy to ease the burden of Cobra insurance payments is running out. Today's Patient Money column offers advice on how to cope.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. In the late 1980s, the nation began to reach one of the many peaks in our century-old "national conversation" on health reform. In that spirit, my wife and I sent a homemade holiday card to our friends in the health policy world.

headline.main: On Health Care, Are Europeans Just Kinder People?

docs.abstract: Maybe it's just cheaper for them to be so generous, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Maybe it's just cheaper for them to be so generous, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democratic leaders delayed a vote because they feared the proposal would be approved, blowing apart a deal negotiated by the White House and the pharmaceutical industry.

docs.lead_paragraph: Preliminary calculations reflect the steep challenges that Senate Democrats face as they await a new cost analysis of their proposal.

headline.main: High Premiums in Senate Democrats’ Health Plan

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Hospital groups are mobilizing against a proposal under consideration by Senate Democrats to let some people ages 55 to 64 buy insurance coverage through Medicare beginning in 2011. Hospitals, doctors and other health care providers often complain that Medicare payment rates are insufficient to cover their expenses. They would rather have patients be covered by private insurance.
docs.abstract: Hospital groups are mobilizing against Medicare buy-in proposal that would let some people ages 55 to 64 buy health insurance coverage through Medicare beginning in 2011; hospitals, doctors and other health care providers often complain that Medicare payment rates are insufficient to cover their expenses (M)

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: For those who want Medicare for all, Medicare for more is not good enough. A few dozen people who want Medicare to be extended to everyone demonstrated Thursday morning at the Manhattan office of Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat who helped negotiate a new proposal in the health care legislation to lower the Medicare eligibility age to 55 from 65.
docs.abstract: Few dozen people who want Medicare coverage extended to everyone demonstrate outside Manhattan offices of Sen Charles Schumer, who has been among most vocal proponents of concept; oppose compromise he helped negotiate to lower Medicare-eligibility age to 55 from 65; demand Schumer use his influence to push for Medicare for all and not settle for half-measures; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For those who want Medicare for all, Medicare for more is not good enough.     A few dozen people who want Medicare to be extended to everyone demonstrated Thursday morning at the Manhattan office of Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat...

docs.lead_paragraph: Twelve percent of Americans aged 55 to 64 -- 4.3 million people -- do not have health insurance, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation. They would be the beneficiaries of a plan being pushed by Senate Democrats as part of the national health care overhaul that would allow people over 55 to buy into the Medicare program at subsidized rates if they can't find coverage elsewhere.
docs.abstract: A Democratic plan to cover people 55 to 64 -- a group hard hit by layoffs.
docs.snippet: A Democratic plan to cover people 55 to 64 -- a group hard hit by layoffs.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted, 56 to 43, on Thursday afternoon to temporarily put aside the major health care legislation and take up a crucial package of spending measures needed to finance many government operations.

headline.main: Senate Pauses on Health Bill to Take Up Spending Measures

docs.abstract: The Senate temporarily put a crucial package of spending measures, needed to finance many government operations, ahead of the continuing debate on health care legislation.
docs.snippet: The Senate temporarily put a crucial package of spending measures, needed to finance many government operations, ahead of the continuing debate on health care legislation.
